sentences_tone.text: Tesla's Settlement Of Falcon Wing Door Lawsuit Yields Fascinating Forensic Findings - Tesla Motors (NASDAQ:TSLA) | Seeking AlphaSign in / Join NowGO»Market NewsStock IdeasDividendsMarket OutlookInvesting StrategyETFs & FundsEarningsPROLong IdeasShort IdeasCramer's PicksIPOsQuick PicksSectorsEditor's PicksTesla's Settlement Of Falcon Wing Door Lawsuit Yields Fascinating Forensic FindingsNov.11.16 | About: Tesla Motors (TSLA) Montana Skeptic Follow Bonds, long-term horizon, portfolio strategy, contrarianSend MessageSummaryFirst things first: why can’t we be friends?On to the main topic: The Hoerbiger lawsuit is dead, but we performed an autopsy before the burial and made three forensic findings.First, the settlement stayed out of the third quarter pie (the one in the naysayers’ face).Second, Tesla’s CEO is suddenly suffering from shyness.Third, the curious incident of the March substitution of legal counsel suggests the SolarCity merger was contemplated well before Tesla’s May capital raise.Would the Trump supporters please stop shaking their fists at Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA)?
Would the Tesla enthusiasts please cool it with all the anguish about Donald Trump?
Can both sides, just for short while, realize that they need to come together?
That they actually have more in common than they realize?
And that they need each other more than they know?
Click to enlarge (Come rest your weary Model X in my garage.
Montana Skeptic photo) There, now, isn't that much better?
We're in this together.
I'm glad we have that out of the way.
Because I want to talk about Tesla's lawsuit against Hoerbiger.
You remember.
The one Tesla filed last January against that terrible Swiss company which slowed down the Model X project by failing to deliver satisfactory falcon wing door hydraulics.
Tesla finally had to go to another supplier to get parts that would make the falcon wing doors function flawlessly.
(They do now function flawlessly, right?
And the door alignments are perfect?)
I've already written about how, in the early stages of the lawsuit, Hoerbiger cleaned Tesla's clock.
And how the clock-cleaning led to a settlement of the dispute in July.
So, let's close the book on Hoerbiger by pointing out two interesting facts, and a third even more interesting fact.
Fact 1: Mouse nuts matter.
Back in July, Tesla and Hoerbiger advised the court they had settled the lawsuit.
But they didn't get around to filing a Stipulation of Dismissal until October 4. Why would that be?
Let's think; what's different about October compared to August or September?

Might it be that October is in Q4, whereas August and September are in Q3? Taking that one step further, might it be that Tesla didn't wish to have the settlement payment occur until Q4 so that the expense would not compromise the pie-in-the-face effect of Q3? Sure, the payment amount was probably relatively small.

"Mouse nuts," as Elon Musk might say (and famously did say during the Q3 earnings call):
Click to enlarge But with Q3 GAAP profits of only $22 million, every mouse nut counted.

(By the way, it's evident from the Third-Quarter 10-Q that the "mouse nuts" revenues of Greenhouse Gas and/or CAFE sales were more than $22 million, and had Musk revealed the amount when he was asked about it by Barclays' Johnson, it would have been evident that Tesla lost money in Q3 on its auto sales.
Why didn't Musk just admit it at the time?
I report; you decide.)
Fact 2: Tesla's CEO has suddenly become shy.
Tesla's CEO constantly tweets about every new development involving his company.

Here are but a few from the past several days: The virtues of solar glass tile:
Click to enlarge Musk's impending interview by the renowned investing genius, Ron Baron:
Click to enlarge The recommendation by Institutional Shareholders Services (ISS) in favor of the merger:
Click to enlarge The recommendation by Glass Lewis & Co. against the merger: Okay, just kidding about that one.
Musk has never tweeted about the fact that Glass Lewis emphatically recommended against the merger, calling it a "thinly-veiled bailout plan."
Indeed, Tesla just sent a notice to its shareholders, urging them to vote for the merger and citing the ISS recommendation, but making no mention of the Glass Lewis condemnation.
SolarCity (NASDAQ:SCTY) did just the same, with the same omission.
And yet, with all Musk's hyperactive tweeting, what did he tweet after Tesla settled its lawsuit against the Swiss devils who sabotaged the Model X?
Not a single word.
Now, why might that be?
What could possibly account for this uncharacteristic taciturnity?
Because unlike the Glass Lewis condemnation, which was bad news, the Hoerbiger settlement was good news, right?
Tesla said it would give it to those guys good and hard for all the dirty deeds they did, and no doubt that's what happened, right?
So, why not tweet it out?
Could it be that, despite having demonized Hoerbiger as the saboteur of the Model X, Tesla actually ended up paying money to Hoerbiger to resolve the lawsuit, instead of vice versa?
And, could it be that Tesla insisted on a confidentiality provision in the settlement agreement so that Hoerbiger cannot reveal who paid whom?
Well, very likely I am wrong, and Tesla's CEO will be on Twitter (NYSE:TWTR) ASAP to debunk my outrageous suggestions.
And in the spirit of fairness, I promise to report back as soon as I read his tweets refuting my surmises.
Fact 3: The merger tick tock just got tickier and tockier.
Remember last May, when Tesla raised $1.7 billion of new capital (and Musk tagged along for another $682 million for himself)?
And remember how awkward it felt to later learn that, back in February, Elon Musk and Lyndon Rive had entered into discussions about a possible merger?
Why awkward?
Because Tesla and Musk had neglected to disclose that fact to the investors who in May had bought their stock for $215 a share.
It's even more awkward now that Tesla's stock price has now dropped by 15%.
Tesla tried to paper over these awkward facts by sketching out a convenient chronology, which it published in its joint Registration Statement for the SolarCity merger.

The Tesla chronology goes like this: Musk and Rive did indeed talk in February about merging their respective companies, and they shared that discussion with their respective boards, but the Tesla board nixed the idea, and revived it only after the May capital raise.

Here's the official account:
In February 2016, Mr. Elon Musk suggested to Mr. Lyndon Rive that he believed more serious consideration of a potential combination between Tesla and SolarCity was in order… This discussion never progressed beyond a high-level, conceptual stage, and no proposal was made at such time.

Following the conceptual discussion between Messrs. Elon Musk and Lyndon Rive, on February 29, 2016, at a special meeting of the Tesla Board, Mr. Jason Wheeler, Tesla's Chief Financial Officer, presented to the Tesla Board preliminary considerations related to product and operational synergies that might result from an acquisition of SolarCity… Following discussion, the Tesla Board determined not to proceed with the evaluation of a potential strategic acquisition of a solar energy company, due to the potential impact on Tesla management's time and resources in light of Tesla's execution of ongoing operational and strategic initiatives, including Tesla's ongoing production ramp of its Model X vehicle.

A little more than three months later on May 31, 2016, following Tesla's continued production improvements, the Tesla Board held a regular meeting… Following discussion, the Tesla Board directed Tesla management to assess a potential acquisition of a solar energy company…The Tesla Board also directed management to instruct Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz (" Wachtell Lipton "), as special outside counsel, to assist in the legal analysis relating to a potential transaction, and to engage an independent financial advisor to assist in a financial analysis of a potential transaction.

Until June 2016, no conclusions were reached and no decisions were taken…
(See pages 57-58 of the Amended S-4 filed on October 11, 2016.
I have rearranged the disclosure in the S-4 to place them in chronological order.)
The Official Tick Tock In condensed form, then, here's the official tick tock: Early February, Musk and Rive talk merger.
Feb. 29, Tesla board claims it decided not to pursue merger.
May 18, Tesla announces Tesla and Musk will sell shares in an equity offering, with no merger disclosure.
May 31, Tesla board decides to proceed with merger after all.
So, there you go.
A nice, neat story that serves as a handy excuse for why Tesla failed to disclose the merger discussions when it raised capital last May.
Yes, it requires some threading of the needle, and a bit of head-scratching about why what was not appealing on February 29 suddenly became irresistible on May 31.
But, at least, it's a story.
The "Disruption" of the Official Tick Tock Except there's just one curious thing that casts doubt on this chronology.
It appears in the Hoerbiger pleadings.
When Tesla sued Hoerbiger back in April, Tesla was represented by the celebrated law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP.

Click to enlarge But then, curiously, on March 29, Tesla had a new law firm substitute in for Skadden, Arps:
Click to enlarge Had Tesla lost faith in Skadden, Arps?
Was there some development in the (very slow moving) lawsuit that caused some terrible friction between attorney and client?
Who decided to take Skadden off the case?
What reason was given to the Tesla Board of Directors?
Was the Board even aware of it?
What about Tesla's eventual merger counsel, the also formidable Wachtell Lipton.
Did it have some conflict with SolarCity that meant it would be unavailable to serve as SolarCity's counsel?
I'm just asking.

I'm just trying to understand why Lyndon Rive would have hired Skadden, Arps to represent SolarCity shortly after his cousin's company had fired that law firm in what it had told the world was an important lawsuit against the Swiss incompetents who had set back the Model X. Because, based on the evidence I see, here's an explanation that makes sense: Tesla wants to take care that Skadden, Arps would have no conflict of interest when the merger was announced so that, as did happen, SolarCity would be free to engage Skadden, Arps - the most formidable corporate merger counsel in the annals of American law - as its merger counsel.
The Revised Tick Tock Here's the revised tick tock, with the new event highlighted: Early February, Musk and Rive talk merger.
Feb. 29, Tesla board claims it decided not to pursue merger.
March 29, Tesla removes Skadden and substitutes new counsel in Hoerbiger lawsuit.
May 18, Tesla announces Tesla and Musk will sell shares in an equity offering, with no merger disclosure.
May 31, Tesla board decides to proceed with merger after all.
If I'm right about the March 29 event, it means Tesla was planning this merger well before the May equity offering.
And it means the lack of disclosure is a problem.
And it means that the "official" explanation in the joint Registration Statement is misleading.

And it means that any shareholders who bought in May at $215 and were stuck with losses after the world learned that Tesla intended to hang a SolarCity anchor around its neck may indeed be justified in raising their eyebrows about the chronology.
Yes, of course, I'm speculating.
Only Tesla has all the facts.
No doubt there are many other, more innocent, explanations, and I invite you to share them with us in the comments section.
The Voice of the Skeptic I enjoyed my conversation with Brian Bain (of Investor in the Family) during our podcast, recorded October 31.
You can hear it here.
Brian's podcasts are always interesting and informative, and you might consider following him to tune in when the topic is in your wheelhouse.
Disclosure: I am/we are short TSLA VIA OPTIONS.
